The synergy between multi-metals can enhance the catalytic performance of catalysts but lacks research from the perspective of reaction mechanisms. Hence, the correlation between the synergy effect and the SCR-C3H6 reaction mechanism was investigated over the CuFe-LDOs catalyst derived from the precursor CuFe-LDHs, and single metal oxide catalysts (CuO, Fe2O3). XPS and H2-TPR techniques reveal the existence of the synergy effect between Cu and Fe, which results in the superior catalytic activity of the CuFe-LDOs catalyst than single metal oxide catalysts, as well as the generation of CuFe2O4 over the CuFe-LDOs catalyst. Numerous static and dynamic In situ DRIFTS and TPSR experiments indicate that the synergy effect encourages the creation of nitrogenous species, especially active intermediates like monodentate, bidentate, and bridging nitrates. Besides, the production of active carboxylate acetate also obtains enhancement owing to the synergy effect. Importantly, R-NCO generates and accumulates profited from the synergy effect, working as the vital intermediate for SCR-C3H6, and is ultimately hydrolyzed to CO2, N2, and H2O. These results demonstrate that the improvement of catalytic activity for the CuFe-LDOs catalyst benefits from the promotion of the synergy effect on active intermediates. Eventually, a possible SCR-C3H6 reaction pathway on the CuFe-LDOs catalyst is established. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords SCR-C3H6 Synergy effect R-NCO Reaction mechanism Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction NOx generated from the combustion of fossil fuels, gives rise to numerous environmental problems such as photochemical smog, acid rain, and so on, as well as harm to human health [1]. Several strategies are adopted to remove NOx, wherein selective catalytic reduction of NO (SCR) technology has emerged as a prevailing method. This technology relies on various reductants, like NH3 (SCR-NH3), H2 (SCR-H2), CO (SCR-CO), hydrocarbons (SCR- HC), etc. SCR-NH3 with mature technology has been applied commercially in fixed sources, but there are also issues related to toxicity, leakage, and storage of NH3 [2]. H2 as a clean fuel works as an alternative to NH3, leading to lower reaction temperature and no secondary pollution. Nevertheless, high costs in the production and storage of H2 limit the application [3]. Given the extensive presence of CO and hydrocarbons in the exhaust gas, SCR-CO and SCR-HC technologies can simultaneously eliminate NOx and CO or hydrocarbons. Whereas, the superior activity and N2 selectivity in excess-oxygen environments remain a significant challenge for SCR-CO technology [4], while SCR-HC technology exhibits better denitrification efficiency under excess-oxygen conditions. Moreover, the advantage of directly using unburned HC without the additional space for storage of reductants makes SCR-HC a promising de-NOx technology, simplifying systems and lowering the after-treatment costs [5,6]. SCR-HC refers to a heterogeneous catalytic reaction, featured by complexity. Hence, the design of heterogeneous catalysts and the surface catalytic reaction mechanism are the research emphases for SCR-HC. To date, great efforts have been made to develop the SCR-HC catalyst system, the active components developing from monometal to multi-metal wherein. As can be found from the previous research, there was a synergy effect between the bi- or multi-metal ions [7,8], resulting in superior catalytic performance than the monometallic catalysts. For the multi-metal SCR-HC catalysts, numerous researches were performed to analyze the interaction between metals from the viewpoints of catalyst synthesis methods [9,10], metal promoters [9,11], support [10,12], texture [10], structure, etc. Nevertheless, research lacks insight into the synergy from the viewpoint of the SCR-HC reaction mechanism. So far, for the SCR-HC reaction mechanism, the redox mechanism has obtained universal recognition [13,14], which involves the adsorption, dispersion, and desorption of reactants on the active sites over catalysts. Given the wide application of Cu and Fe as active metals, Table 1 lists the intermediates produced by reactants for different Cu- and Fe-based multi-metal catalysts. As can be seen, the type, activity, and vital evolution pathway of intermediates vary from catalysts, and they are crucial information to reveal the SCR-HC reaction mechanism. Hence, to lucubrate the synergy between bi- and multi-metals, it is necessary to reveal the relationship between the above information of intermediates and the synergy effect. As mentioned above, benefiting from the high catalytic activity at medium and low temperatures of Cu [19,20], and high resistance to SO2/H2O and N2 selectivity of Fe [21,22], Cu- and Fe-based catalysts attracted extensive attention. Layered double hydroxides (LDHs), with the formula described as [M2+ 1-xM3+ x(OH)2]x+[(An-)x/n]x-•mH2O, provide an excellent platform for investigating the multimetallic catalyst, profiting from their flexible chemical composition, precise concentration control, and excellent dispersion of metal ions at an atom level. Inspired by the advantages of Cu, Fe, and LDHs, in this contribution, one kind of SCR-HC catalyst derived from the binary CuFe-LDHs was synthesized, named CuFe-LDOs. Compared with the single metal oxide catalysts (CuO, Fe2O3), the synergy between Cu and Fe on the CuFe-LDOs catalyst was revealed via X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) and Temperature-programmed reduction with H2 (H2-TPR) techniques. Subsequently, a series of static and dynamic In situ diffuse reflectance fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (In situ DRIFTS) experiments were carried out to gain insight into the synergy from the viewpoint of the SCR-HC reaction mechanism. 2 Experimental 2.1 Synthesis of catalysts CuO and Fe2O3 were prepared via the precipitation method. Salt solution was obtained by dissolving Cu(NO3)2•6H2O or Fe(NO3)3•9H2O into 50 mL of deionized water, and precipitant was obtained by dissolving NaOH 50 mL of deionized water. Then the precipitant was added to the salt solution to get a suspension, and the metal oxide was obtained after centrifuging, washing, drying, and calcination in turn. CuFe-LDOs catalyst was synthesized via the coprecipitation method. The mixed solution A was prepared by dissolving Cu(NO3)2•6H2O and Fe(NO3)3•9H2O into 50 mL of deionized water with a molar rate of Cu/Fe of 2. The Na2CO3 with the same molar as that of Fe3+, together with NaOH of 0.04 mol were dissolved into the deionized water of 50 mL to prepare the mixed solution B as the precipitant. Subsequently, under vigorous stirring, solution A and solution B were co-dropped into a breaker containing deionized water of 200 mL, keeping the dropping rate of 1 mL/min and pH at 4.8±0.2. The suspension obtained was further stirred at 70 °C for 24 h, followed by centrifuging and washing several times. The wet cake was dried at 80 °C for 12 h to gain the precursor CuFe-LDHs. Eventually, after calcination at 600 °C for 4 h, the precursor was converted into the catalyst, denoted as CuFe-LDOs. 2.2 Catalytic activity measurements The SCR-C3H6 activity measurements for the catalysts were carried out on a fixed-bed reactor equipped with a quartz tube with a diameter of 8 mm. After the pretreatment at 300 °C under N2 atmosphere for 30 min, 0.4 g of catalyst was exposed to the mixed reaction gases with a total flow rate of 200 mL/min, with a composition of 0.05% NO, 0.1% C3H6, 2% O2, 5% H2O, 0.02% SO2, and N2 as the balance gas. NO, NO2, and N2O concentrations were recorded by a flue gas analyzer (ECOM-J2KN). C3H6 was detected by FID with a KB-Al2O3/Na2SO4 column equipped in GC-4000A. NO and C3H6 conversions and N2 selectivity were calculated according to the following equations: (1) NO c o n v e r s i o n = [ NO ] in − [ NO ] out [ NO ] in × 100 % (2) N 2 selectivity = [ NO ] in − [ NO ] out − 2 [ N 2 O ] out − [ NO 2 ] out [ NO ] in − [ NO ] out × 100 (3) C 3 H 6 conversion = [ C 3 H 6 ] in − [ C 3 H 6 ] out [ C 3 H 6 ] in × 100 The turnover frequency (TOF) was calculated according to the following equation: (4) TOF = 3600 ( P F NO RT ) C NO m β / M Wherein, P is the atmospheric pressure at standard conditions (0.1 MPa), FNO represents the flow rate of NO (0.1 mL/min=1.67 × 10−9 m3/s), R is the proportional constant (8.134 Pa m3 mol−1 k−1), T is 298 K, CNO is the NO conversion at 300 °C (%), m refers to the mass of the catalyst (0.4 g), β represents the surface content of Cu or Fe obtained by XPS, and M is the atomic mass of Cu (64 g/mol) or Fe (56 g/mol). 2.3 Catalyst characterization The N2 adsorption-desorption was operated at -196 °C on Micromeritics ASAP 2460 analyzer (Micromeritics, USA) to detect the textural properties of samples. Before each measurement, the sample was pretreated at 200 °C for 6 h. SEM was carried out to observe the micromorphology of samples using a ZEISS sigma500 (Zeiss, Germany), with a beam current of 60 μA and an accelerating voltage of 20 kV. X-ray diffraction (XRD) was used to analyze the crystal structure and phases of samples, which were conducted on a D/max-2550 diffractometer (Rigaku, Japan) with a Cu Kα radiation (λ=0.154056 nm) source, and operated at 40 kV and 150 mA, in the 2θ range of 5–80° at a scan rate of 2°/min. The X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS), employed to analyze the chemical states of elements on the surface of samples, were collected with a Thermo Escalab 250Xi instrument (Thermo, USA) with Al-Kα (1486.6 eV) as the X-ray source. Temperature-programmed reduction (TPR) experiments were carried out on a gas chromatograph analyzer GC-4000A (EWAI, China). After the pretreatment under N2 atmosphere at 300 °C for 0.5 h and cooling down to ambient temperature, 0.1 g sample was heated from ambient temperature to 700 °C at a heating rate of 3 °C/min, under a flow rate of 20 ml/min (5% H2 and 95% N2). The TCD automatically recorded data every 15 °C. 2.4 In situ DRIFTS measurements In situ DRIFTS experiments were used to probe into the active and inert intermediates and their evolutionary properties, which were conducted on a Nicolet IS50 (Thermo, USA) spectrometer equipped with the MCT/A detector detection at a resolution of 4 cm-1 and an average of 64 scans. The reaction temperatures were controlled by an automatic temperature controller (HARRICK). Before each experiment, the catalyst (∼50 mg) underwent a pretreatment at 500 °C for 1 h under the N2 atmosphere to remove surface impurities. Subsequently, during cooling down to the ambient temperature, the background spectra at the target temperatures were collected. Eventually, the catalyst was exposed to a reaction gas mixture at ambient temperature, with a total gas flow rate of 20 mL/min, containing 0.05% NO, 0.1% C3H6, 2% O2, and N2. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Influence of synergy effect on catalytic activity Fig. 1 exhibits the temperature dependence of catalytic performance over CuO, Fe2O3, and CuFe-LDOs catalysts. In Fig. 1(a), for single metal oxide catalysts CuO and Fe2O3, NO conversions exhibit a relatively obvious increase above 350 °C. Whereas, the CuFe-LDOs catalyst achieves NO conversion above 40% over the entire reaction temperature window, and the maximum value of 60% in the range of 250–350 °C therein. Moreover, NO conversion of the CuFe-LDOs catalyst outclasses those of CuO and Fe2O3 in the whole region of reaction temperature, indicating that the synergy between Cu and Fe exists and promotes the catalytic activity. Similarly, as depicted in Fig. 1(b), the CuFe-LDOs catalyst exhibits superior N2 selectivity than those of CuO and Fe2O3 catalysts over the entire reaction temperature range, which proves the synergy between Cu and Fe and enhances the reduction of NO to N2 by C3H6. Moreover, in the range of 250–350 °C, the CuFe-LDOs catalyst achieves N2 selectivity of 100 %. With further increase in temperature, N2 selectivity undergoes a drop due to the lack of C3H6 for the reduction of NO, caused by the fact that more C3H6 participates in combustion reaction. Different from the complete consumption of C3H6 over CuFe-LDOs catalyst, C3H6 is still available up to 450 °C over single metal oxide catalysts, as shown in Fig. 1(c). This phenomenon illustrates the facilitation of C3H6 conversion profiting from the synergy between Cu and Fe. Fig. 2 shows the long-term resistance to H2O and/or SO2 at 350 °C over these catalysts. Without H2O and SO2, NO conversion tends to stabilize progressively after 20 min. After doping H2O, NO conversion first drops sharply and then maintains a stable level, which is 53% for the CuFe-LDOs catalyst while less than 5% for single metal oxide catalysts. On switching off H2O, the NO conversion for the CuFe-LDOs catalyst restores to the original level, different from the loss of activity for single metal oxide catalysts. Similarly, after introducing SO2, all catalysts experience a decrease in NO conversion. Differently, NO conversion does not return to the initial level after switching off SO2. The co-presence of H2O and SO2 was also investigated, as shown in Fig. 2(c). The co-introduction of H2O and SO2 significantly decreases the NO conversion of these catalysts. Even after H2O and SO2 vanishing, NO conversion remains below the original level, featured by a loss of 9% for CuO, 7% for Fe2O3, and 5% for the CuFe-LDOs catalyst. Overall, the long-term tolerance to H2O and/or SO2 of the CuFe-LDOs is superior to those of single metal oxide catalysts. 3.2 The analysis of synergy between Cu and Fe XRD spectra were collected to clarify the crystallite phases of samples, as depicted in Fig. 3 . Single metal oxide catalysts present CuO (JCPDS: 89–5899) and Fe2O3 (JCPDS: 33–0664) phases respectively, with the single crystal phase and high crystallinity. In terms of CuFe-LDHs, the spectrum displays the typical LDHs diffraction peaks at 2θ of 12.8, 25.8, 33.6, 36.6, 43.6 and 61°, corresponding to (003), (006), (012), (015), (018) and (110) crystal planes for LDHs respectively [23]. Compared with CuFe-LDHs, the CuFe-LDOs catalyst occurs significant alterations in diffraction peaks, implying that the layer structure suffers from collapse and topological transformation to other crystallite phases. Compared with the standard spectra of CuO, Fe2O3, and CuFe2O4 (JCPDS: 77–0010), it can be determined that CuO is the primary crystallite phase for the CuFe-LDOs catalyst while CuFe2O4 and Fe2O3 act as minor phases. Thereinto, CuO, Fe2O3, and CuFe2O4 phases overlap at 2θ≈35.6°, index to the (-111), (110), and (311) crystal planes for CuO, Fe2O3, and CuFe2O4, respectively. According to the report, the synergy between bimetals encourages the formation of composite metal oxides rather than single metal oxides [24]. Hence, the creation of the spinel CuFe2O4 phase provides proof of the synergy between Cu and Fe. Ulteriorly, the XPS spectra of Cu2p and Fe2p for these catalysts were captured, as displayed in Fig. 4 . For single metal oxide catalysts, as depicted in Fig. 4(a) and Fig. 4(b), Cu2p3/2 and Cu2p1/2 peaks are centered at BE of the 933.6 and 953.6 eV for the CuO catalyst, while Fe2p3/2 and Fe2p1/2 of Fe2O3 catalyst at 710.6 and 724.3 eV, respectively. Regarding the CuFe-LDOs catalyst (in Fig. 4(c) and Fig. 4(d)), according to the previous studies, Cu and Fe exist on the catalyst surface at the valences of +2 and +3 respectively [25], featured by the core levels of Cu2p3/2 and Cu2p1/2 lying at 933.8 and 953.5 eV whereas the core levels of Fe2p3/2 and Fe2p1/2 at 711.3 and 724.3 eV. As compared with the BE of CuO (933.6 eV) and Fe2O3 (710.6 eV), both the core levels of Cu2p3/2 and Fe2p3/2 for the CuFe-LDOs catalyst have a shift, proving that the synergy between Cu and Fe leads to different coordination environments. Therefore, according to the distinct coordination environments, Cu2p3/2 and Fe2p3/2 are both separated into two peaks. Thereinto, for Cu2p3/2, two peaks at BE of ca. 933.4 and 934.9 eV are in assignment with the Cu2+ coordinated in CuO and CuFe2O4, respectively [24,26]. In terms of Fe2p3/2, two peaks located at BE of ca. 710.4 and 712.7 eV, correspond to Fe3+ lying in Fe2O3 and CuFe2O4, respectively [24]. These results indicate that the synergy exists between Cu and Fe, and leads to the formation of the spinel CuFe2O4, in agreement with the XRD result. Moreover, the surface content of Cu and Fe also can be obtained by XPS, as listed in Table 2 . Based on these, TOF was calculated using the Eq. (4), as depicted in Table 2. As well known, TOF is related to active sites, the higher the TOF value, the better the SCR activity [27]. For the CuFe-LDOs catalyst, the TOF is 0.1 h-1, higher than those of CuO and Fe2O3 catalysts, possibly due to the improvement of active sites caused by the synergy effect between Cu and Fe. Fig. 5 displays the micromorphology of CuO, Fe2O3, and CuFe-LDOs catalysts. As can be seen, both CuO with bulk morphology and Fe2O3 with particle deposition morphology present hardly visible pore structures. On the contrary, the CuFe-LDOs catalyst has a relatively abundant pore structure due to the irregular stacking nanoplatelet. The difference in richness of pore structure between mono-metal oxide catalysts and the CuFe-LDOs catalyst, leads to the difference in specific surface area, as shown in Table 2. The CuFe-LDOs catalyst exhibits a higher specific surface area than mono-metal oxide catalysts, which might profit from the enhancement in the richness of pore structure due to the synergy effect between bi-metals. Fig. 6 shows the H2-TPR profiles of catalysts. As can be seen, a strong reduction peak exists for the CuO catalyst in the region from 250 °C to 600 °C, with a peak value at 535 °C, corresponding to the reduction of CuO to Cu0. In the case of Fe2O3, three distinct reduction peaks appear at 394, 617, and 750 °C in the range of 350–800 °C, attributed to the stepwise reduction of Fe2O3→Fe3O4→FeO→Fe [28], respectively. Different from CuO and Fe2O3, the H2-TPR curve for the CuFe-LDOs catalyst presents two reduction zones in the region of 250–600 °C, which are deconvoluted into five reduction peaks centered at temperatures of 286, 313, 394, 484, and 550 °C. According to some reports, CuO was reduced to Cu in the temperature range of 200–300 °C [16,19,24], whereas the reduction of CuFe2O4 to metal Cu and Fe2O3 occurred in the range of 200–450 °C companied by a rapid reduction of Fe2O3 to Fe3O4 [24,29]. Therefore, two reduction peaks at 286 °C and 313 °C can be assigned to the reduction of CuO and CuFe2O4, respectively. The other three reduction peaks located at 394, 484, and 550 °C are due to the stepwise reduction of Fe2O3 species. Compared with the CuO catalyst, the reduction peak of copper species over the CuFe-LDOs catalyst shifts toward lower temperatures. Similarly, the iron species of the CuFe-LDOs catalyst are also reduced at lower temperatures than those of the Fe2O3 catalyst, since the H2 spillover effect of copper leads to the shift of reduction temperatures toward lower temperatures [30]. These phenomena prove the existence of a synergy between copper and iron, which results in the reduction temperature of the catalyst moving to lower temperatures. As a result, the reduction property for the catalyst gets enhancements, being responsible for the superior catalytic activity of the CuFe-LDOs catalyst to those of the CuO and Fe2O3. 3.3 In situ DRIFTS analysis To investigate the impact of the synergy between Cu and Fe on adsorption products and active intermediates, a series of static and dynamic In situ DRIFTS experiments were carried out over these three catalysts, and the assignment of these adsorption peaks is shown in Table 3 . Thereinto, there is a deviation in the location of the absorption peaks indexed to the same species on different catalyst surfaces, due to the variations in the active components over these catalysts. 3.3.1 NO+O2 static adsorption NO adsorbed on the catalyst surface will lead to various nitrogenous species with different thermal stability. Therefore, to eliminate the wrong cognition that some nitrogenous species are identified as active species when they disappear due to their poor thermal stability, NO+O2 adsorption was conducted over these catalysts at 30 and 300 °C respectively, and the spectra after saturation adsorption are depicted in Fig. 7 . After the saturation adsorption of NO+O2 at 30 °C, as shown in Fig. 7(a), gas-phase NO (1901, 1842 cm-1) [31], bridging (1630 cm-1) [32,33], bidentate (1600 cm-1) [31,34], chelating nitro compounds(1504 cm-1) [32], nitro compounds (1402 cm-1) [32], and monodentate nitrate (1295 cm-1) [35] appear on the CuO catalyst surface. Among these nitrogenous species, slight active sites on CuO may be responsible for the appearance of gas-phase NO, meaning that NO has a non-complete conversion to nitrate species. Comparing the intensities of these adsorption peaks, bridging and bidentate nitrates are the dominant nitrogenous species for the CuO catalyst. For Fe2O3 catalyst, except bridging (1630 cm-1), bidentate (1600 cm-1), and monodentate (1540, 1273 cm-1) [32,35] nitrates, N2O4 (1740 cm-1) [33] and nitrite/nitro compounds (1360 cm-1) species [32] also are observed, wherein, N2O4 and bridging nitrate are the main species. Moreover, N2O4 may be related to Fe sites because of its absence on the CuO catalyst. Regarding the CuFe-LDOs catalyst, owing to the co-existence and interaction of Cu and Fe sites, both of N2O4 (1724 cm-1), bridging (1630, 1183 cm-1) [31,36], bidentate (1600, cm-1), monodentate (1485, 1290 cm-1) [32,35,36] nitrates, and nitrite/nitro compounds (1360 cm-1) species appear and exhibit higher intensity than those on CuO and Fe2O3 catalysts, thereinto, bridging and monodentate nitrates are the primary nitrogenous species. This phenomenon illustrates the promotion in the formation of nitrogenous species induced by the synergy between Cu and Fe. Distinctly, adsorption peaks for the spectra at 300 °C vary from those at 30 °C in shape and intensity, as shown in Fig. 7(b). Compared with the spectra at 30 °C for CuO, gas-phase NO still appears in the spectra of NO+O2 adsorption at 300 °C, further revealing the small number of sites to adsorb NO over the CuO catalyst. Furthermore, the same nitrogenous species are noticed, like bridging, bidentate, and monodentate nitrates, among them, bridging and bidentate nitrates working as the main species has no change. Differently, chelating nitro compounds and nitro compounds disappear, implying their poor thermal stability. Similarly, some species still appear on the Fe2O3 catalyst surface, namely bridging, bidentate, monodentate nitrates, and nitrite/nitro compounds, whereas N2O4 disappears. Note that nitrite/nitro compounds supersede N2O4 and became the primary species along with bridging nitrate, probably since N2O4 occurs conversion to nitrite/nitro compounds with increasing temperature owing to its poor thermal stability. Regarding the CuFe-LDOs catalyst, after the saturation adsorption of NO+O2 at 300 °C, only bridging, bidentate, and monodentate nitrates grow, whilst, N2O4 and nitrite/nitro compounds are absent. In addition, bidentate nitrates increase in strength to become the dominant adsorbed species, suggesting that weakly stabilized N2O4 and nitrite/nitro compounds may be converted to bidentate nitrates. The higher intensity of adsorbed species over the CuFe-LDOs catalyst than those over CuO and Fe2O3 catalysts further implies that the synergy between Cu and Fe enhances the generation of bridging, bidentate, and monodentate nitrates. 3.3.2 C3H6+O2 static adsorption The oxygen-containing hydrocarbon species generated from the adsorption of another reactant C3H6 were also recorded at different temperatures, and the spectra are displayed in Fig. 8 . Fig. 8(a) shows the spectra of saturation adsorption of C3H6+O2 at 30 °C. Referring to the attribution of these adsorption peaks in Table 3, adsorbed C3H6 denoted as ad-C3H6 (1666, 1646 cm-1) [31,37], νs(COO) from acetate (1470 cm-1) [40], νs(COO) from acetate or carbonate (1443 cm-1) [31,34,42,43], and δ(CH) (1395 cm-1) [35,38] from formate generate on the CuO catalyst surface. Similar to the CuO catalyst, some ad-C3H6 also are observed at 1666 and 1646 cm-1, and δ(CH) originating from formate appears at 1392 cm-1 on the Fe2O3 catalyst surface. Interestingly, acetate exhibits several adsorption peaks at 1575, 1470, 1357, and 1290 cm-1, corresponding to νas(COO), νs(COO), δ(CH3), and ν(C-C), respectively [37,40–42,44]. Besides, another two adsorption peaks at 1720 and 1175 cm-1 are ascribed to carbonyl ν(C=O) and ν(C-O) [22,35,41]. Profiting from Cu and Fe double sites, both species growing on CuO and Fe2O3 catalysts are noted on the CuFe-LDOs catalyst, including ν(C=O) (1723 cm-1), ad-C3H6 (1658, 1628 cm-1), νas(COO) (1598 cm-1) [38,39], νs(COO) (1480 cm-1) and δ(CH) (1395 cm-1) from formate [35,38,41], νs(COO) (1470 cm-1), δ(CH3) (1357 cm-1), and ν(C-C) (1290 cm-1) form acetate [40–42,44], as well as ν(C-O) (1180 cm-1) [41]. Comparing the intensity of carboxylate (CxHyOz) produced on these three catalysts, it can be found that formate and acetate coexist on the CuFe-LDOs catalyst with higher intensity than those of CuO and Fe2O3 catalysts. This phenomenon demonstrates that the synergy between Cu and Fe promotes the formation of carboxylate on account of the higher adsorption intensity of carboxylate for CuFe-LDOs than those for CuO and Fe2O3 catalysts. Fig. 8(b) shows the DRIFT spectra of the saturation adsorption of C3H6+O2 at 300 °C. As can be seen, the amount and intensity of adsorption peaks suffer from significant change. For the CuO catalyst, ad-C3H6 together with νs(COO) from acetate and/or carbonate species are also noticed. A new peak assigned to νas(COO) from acetate appears at 1568 cm-1 companying with the disappearance of δ(CH) from formate, illustrating the poor thermal stability of formate. In terms of Fe2O3 catalyst, these adsorption peaks in the interval of 1000–1400 cm-1 disappear. On the contrary, the intensities of these peaks in the range of 1400–1800 cm-1 get enhancement, corresponding species including ad-C3H6, carbonyl, acetate, and carbonate (1520, 1430 cm-1) [43]. The absence of formate and partial acetate, as well as the presence of carbonate indicate that C3H6 adsorbed on the Fe2O3 catalyst surface is easy to convert into carbonate rather than carboxylate at higher temperatures. Interestingly, on the CuFe-LDOs catalyst surface, other species disappear except acetate, revealing that C3H6 is activated to acetate with high thermal stability when rising temperature. 3.3.3 Identification of active and inert intermediates Adsorption species work as active or inert intermediates in the reaction process, hence, some dynamic In situ DRIFTS experiments were conducted to distinguish the activity of these species. Fig. 9 displays the DRIFT spectra of C3H6 adsorption after saturation of NO+O2 at 300 °C over these three catalysts. As for the CuO catalyst, gas phase NO also appears after introducing C3H6, revealing that gas phase NO is unable to react directly with C3H6. With the injection of C3H6 progressing, bridging nitrate steadily decreases while bidentate and monodentate nitrates vanish, illustrating that bridging, bidentate, and monodentate nitrates are the active intermediates. Meanwhile, ad-C3H6 and acetate or carbonate (1440 cm-1) appear and accumulate over time. Concerning the Fe2O3 catalyst, monodentate, bridging, and bidentate nitrates, as well as nitrite/nitro compounds function as active intermediates, which can be interpreted as that these species participate in the reaction, thus resulting in the weakness or disappearance in the intensity of their adsorption peaks. As time goes on, ad-C3H6, ν(C=O), and formate arise and progressively amass. In addition, it is worth noting that the adsorption peak at 1540 cm-1 shifts to 1542 cm-1, corresponding to monodentate nitrate and acetate respectively, and acetate accumulates inch by inch. As to the CuFe-LDOs catalyst, as time goes on, bridging, bidentate, and monodentate nitrates gradually disappear, accompanied by the emergence of acetate. In particular, it is worth noting that a new peak assigned to isocyanate R-NCO appears at 2180 cm-1 [15] but is absent on CuO and Fe2O3 catalysts. Combined with the catalytic activity of these catalysts, it can be induced that R-NCO is the vital active intermediate for the SCR-C3H6 reaction, and its generation is thanks to the synergy effect between Cu and Fe. Moreover, through comprehensive analysis, bridging and bidentate nitrates are active intermediates for these three catalysts. Fig. 10 shows the DRIFT spectra of NO adsorption after saturation of C3H6+O2 at 300 °C. For the CuO catalyst, with the injection of NO, in company with the decrease of adsorbed C3H6, the intensity of gas phase NO increases, demonstrating that NO competes for adsorption with unactivated C3H6 at the active sites. Moreover, acetate species gradually decrease, indicating that they work as active intermediates. However, the intensity of the adsorption peak at 1440 cm-1 has no variation, hence, it can be indexed to CO3 2- due to its inertia for reaction. No distinct change arises on the Fe2O3 catalyst, which may be because oxygenated hydrocarbon species exhibit strong adsorption ability on the Fe sites, as a result, the activation of NO suffers from inhibition, thereby influencing the reaction between nitrogenous species and oxygenated hydrocarbon species. For the CuFe-LDOs catalyst, the intensity of adsorption peaks indexed to acetate gradually decreases over time, revealing the activity of acetate. In addition, among these peaks, the peak at 1542 cm-1 assigned to νas(COO) has a shift towards 1540 cm-1 (monodentate nitrate) with the process of injecting NO. Similarly, R-NCO species also appear when introducing NO after the saturation of C3H6+O2, and they are absent on single metal oxide catalysts. This phenomenon indicates that the synergy between Cu and Fe encourages the creation of R-NCO species, resulting in superior catalytic activity for the CuFe-LDOs catalyst. 3.3.4 Temperature-programmed surface reaction (TPSR) over catalysts Temperature-programmed surface reaction experiment was conducted to reveal the microscopic reaction pathway for these catalysts, and the spectra corresponding to each target temperature are depicted in Fig. 11 . For the CuO catalyst (in Fig. 9(a)), after the saturation adsorption of C3H6+NO+O2 at ambient temperature, gas NO (1842 cm-1), ad-C3H6 (1666 cm-1), bridging nitrate (1630 cm-1), monodentate nitrate (1472, 1295 cm-1), acetate (νs(COO), 1440 cm-1), and formate (δ(CH), 1395 cm-1) are observed on the surface. With the reaction temperature increasing to 200 °C, gas NO, adsorbed C3H6, monodentate, and bridging nitrates gradually decrease, at the same time, νas(COO) from acetate appears and accumulates at 1540 cm-1. This phenomenon may be caused by the activation of adsorbed C3H6 to acetate. With the further increase in reaction temperature, both these species disappear bit by bit, indicating that these nitrates react with carboxylates to produce N2, H2O, and CO2. In addition, it is uncertain of the activity of formate, owing to its weak thermal stability proved by Fig. 8. As shown in Fig. 11(b), N2O4 or carbonyl (1720 cm-1), ad-C3H6 (1660 cm-1), bridging nitrate (1630 cm-1), bidentate nitrate (1600 cm-1), νas(COO) (1560 cm-1) and νs(COO) (1440 cm-1) from acetate, monodentate nitrate (1540 cm-1), formate (δ(CH), 1390 cm-1), and ν(C-C) (1290 cm-1) [44] are present on the Fe2O3 catalyst surface. Different from the CuO catalyst, according to the variation of the intensity of these species, as the reaction temperature rises to 250 °C, bridging, bidentate, and monodentate nitrates grow steadily. Apart from these nitrates, carboxylates including formate and acetate also continually accumulate. The accumulation of nitrates and carboxylates benefits from the activation of N2O4 and C3H6 respectively, proved by the decrease in intensity of absorbed peaks indexed to N2O4 and C3H6 species. With the further increase in temperature, these nitrates and carboxylates gradually vanish as they react with each other to create final products, like N2, CO2, and H2O. After the saturation adsorption of C3H6+NO+O2 over the CuFe-LDOs catalyst (in Fig. 11(c)), six evident peaks are present at 1723, 1666, 1630, 1600, 1560, and region of 1500–1200 cm-1, corresponding to N2O4, ad-C3H6, bridging nitrate, bidentate nitrate, νas(COO) from acetate, and multi-species coupling. Wherein, combining the results of Fig. 7 and Fig. 8, the overlapping peak in the range of 1500–1200 cm-1 includes νs(COO) from acetate (1440 cm-1), δ(CH) from formate (1390 cm-1), nitrite/nitro compounds or δ(CH3) (1360 cm-1), and monodentate nitrate (1270 cm-1). Therefore, at 30 °C, reactants are adsorbed on the catalyst surface to form ad-C3H6, carboxylate CxHyOz, nitrite/nitro compounds, and various nitrates. As the temperature increases to 150 °C, in company with the decrease of formate and ad-C3H6, acetate (1560, 1440 cm-1) constantly accumulates, demonstrating the conversion of ad-C3H6 into acetate. The disappearance of formate may be caused by the participation in the reaction, proved by the presence and amassing of R-NCO located at 2180 cm-1. At the same time, N2O4 and nitrates gradually decrease, probably resulting from participating in the oxidization of C3H6 into carboxylate CxHyOz as strong oxidants. With increasing the temperature to 200 °C, acetate and nitrate species are consumed inch by inch, whereas the intensity of R-NCO obtains enhancement, revealing that CxHyOz reacts with nitrate to form R-NCO species. With an increase in temperature from 200 °C, acetate, nitrate, and R-NCO species gradually disappear, wherein, the vanish of R-NCO is due to the hydrolysis of isocyanate, and ultimately to N2, CO2, and H2O. In addition, the combustion of C3H6 turns into a predominance reaction at high temperatures, becoming the main generation source of CO2. To sum up, the synergy effect between Cu and Fe evidenced by XPS and H2-TPR affects the active intermediates and their evolution, leading to the difference in catalytic performance of catalysts. Comparing the static In situ DRIFTS of catalysts, it can be induced that the synergy effect enhances the formation of nitrogenous species and CxHyOz species on the CuFe-LDOs catalyst surface, especially the active intermediates inferred by dynamic In situ DRIFTS, namely monodentate, bidentate, and bridging nitrates as well as acetate. Additionally, the synergy effect facilitates the activation of C3H6 to acetate at low temperatures, due to the absence of ad-C3H6 on the CuFe-LDOs catalyst while the presence of that on CuO and Fe2O3 catalysts at the high temperature. Noteworthily, the synergy effect contributes to forming the vital active intermediate R-NCO, since it only appears on the CuFe-LDOs catalyst. According to the difference in TPSR spectra, the temperature where reactants occur activation and evolution after adsorption on the CuFe-LDOs catalyst is lower than those for mono-metal oxide catalysts. This demonstrates that the synergy effect accelerates the activation and evolution of reactants at low temperatures, thereby improving the catalytic performance of the CuFe-LDOs catalyst. 3.4 The microscopic reaction pathway for CuFe-LDOs Fig. 12 exhibits the microscopic reaction pathway of SCR-C3H6 over the CuFe-LDOs catalyst. After the adsorption of mixed reactant consisting of NO, C3H6, and O2 at room temperature, nitrates (bridging, bidentate, monodentate), nitrite/nitro compounds, N2O4, adsorbed C3H6, acetate, and formate species are produced on the CuFe-LDOs catalyst surface. As the reaction temperature rises, nitrite/nitro compounds and N2O4 experience the conversion into bidentate nitrates with high thermal stability (denoted as the red line). Nitrates play a double role. On the one hand, due to their strong oxidability, nitrates take part in the oxidation of adsorbed C3H6 into acetate (denoted as the green line). On the other hand, nitrates react with acetate to form R-NCO species (denoted as the purple line). Subsequently, R-NCO species are ultimately hydrolyzed to CO2, N2, and H2O. In addition, in the whole reaction process, especially at high temperatures, there exists the competitive reaction of selective activation of C3H6, namely the combustion of C3H6 (denoted as the yellow line). 4 Conclusions In this contribution, with CuO and Fe2O3 as the control groups, the synergy effect between Cu and Fe for the CuFe-LDOs catalyst is confirmed to exist via XPS and H2-TPR technologies, which is responsible for the improvement of SCR-C3H6 catalytic activity. Based on that, a series of static and dynamic In situ DRIFTS, and TPSR experiments are ulteriorly conducted to investigate the relationship between the synergy and SCR-C3H6 reaction. According to these results, the synergy promotes the formation of active intermediates, namely nitrates (monodentate, bidentate, bridging), acetate, and R-NCO species. Whereinto, the R-NCO plays a crucial role in the enhancement of SCR-C3H6 activity, due to its presence on the CuFe-LDOs catalyst whereas its absence on CuO and Fe2O3 catalysts. Finally, a possible SCR-C3H6 reaction pathway on the CuFe-LDOs catalyst is proposed. coredata.dc:description: The synergy between multi-metals can enhance the catalytic performance of catalysts but lacks research from the perspective of reaction mechanisms. Hence, the correlation between the synergy effect and the SCR-C3H6 reaction mechanism was investigated over the CuFe-LDOs catalyst derived from the precursor CuFe-LDHs, and single metal oxide catalysts (CuO, Fe2O3). XPS and H2-TPR techniques reveal the existence of the synergy effect between Cu and Fe, which results in the superior catalytic activity of the CuFe-LDOs catalyst than single metal oxide catalysts, as well as the generation of CuFe2O4 over the CuFe-LDOs catalyst. Numerous static and dynamic In situ DRIFTS and TPSR experiments indicate that the synergy effect encourages the creation of nitrogenous species, especially active intermediates like monodentate, bidentate, and bridging nitrates. Besides, the production of active carboxylate acetate also obtains enhancement owing to the synergy effect. Importantly, R-NCO generates and accumulates profited from the synergy effect, working as the vital intermediate for SCR-C3H6, and is ultimately hydrolyzed to CO2, N2, and H2O. These results demonstrate that the improvement of catalytic activity for the CuFe-LDOs catalyst benefits from the promotion of the synergy effect on active intermediates. Eventually, a possible SCR-C3H6 reaction pathway on the CuFe-LDOs catalyst is established.
